description.narrative: The Accelerator Labs are UNDP’s new way of working in development. Zimbabwe is part of a global network of 60 other COs setting up labs to find new approaches that fit the complexity of fast evolving development challenges.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses. 2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies 3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative: 1. Zimbabwe Country Accelerator Lab established 2.The Country Office and its partners have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions 3. New sustainable development solutions are scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets 4. National learning and scaling network is established

Target 1: 2 new sources of data per year Target 2: 3 different type of data sources per year Target 3: 20 new potential solutions per lab per year Target 4: 2 innovation methods per Action Plan Target 5: 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year.

Target 1: 10 new sources of data per year Target 2: 9 different type of data sources per year Target 3: 50 new potential solutions per lab per year Target 4: 10 innovation methods per Action Plan Target 5: 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year

Target 1: 10 new sources of data per year 1. Surveys to gauge digital literacy among youth for Young Innovators Program (YIP) 2. Radio feed back data from running YIP adverts 3. Questionnaires to set ABC baselines 4. Quizzes to collect data on digital readiness internally 5. Public record scrapping for Urban Agriculture study for the Next Gen Cities Programme 6. GIS mapping for Urban Agriculture study 7. In person interviews for research for the Next Gen Cities Programme w 8. Social media and online web data for analyzing demographics and reach of the Youth Connekt business case 9. Mobile surveys for base-lining of YIP 10. Field visits for Urban Agriculture
Target 2: 9 different type of data sources per year 1. Questionnaires 2. Social media 3. Focus group discussions 4. Public records 5. GIS mapping 6. In person field visits 7. Mobile Surveys
Target 4:10 innovation methods per Action Plan - 10 innovation methods identified Food Supply Chain Innovations; 1. Innovative Farming through nutrition gardens on public land to increase access to nutritious affordable food 2. Data platform for tracking and monitoring loan performance in the form of a credit index 3. Research on supply chains and urban markets 4. Agridata platform for collection of production and consumption data across 59 districts in Zimbabwe as means to study supply chains and gaps Borderlands Innovations; 5. ABC Innovation Challenge to improve financial operating environment for women and youth Small Scale Cross Border Traders (SSCBTs) through digitization, and use of mobile money platform for 100 Cross Border Traders. Trade and Data Innovations; 6. UNDP/UNESCO Creatives Regional for Development Platform focused on data sharing/peer to peer exchange and African Trade Agreement activities 7. Drones for Country Office Programmes
Target 3: 50 new potential solutions per lab per year; 50 Solutions were sourced through country office unit events and through our solutions mapping field missions, with particular focus on innovations that focused on agriculture, waste management and resilience. Please check solution atlas for uploaded solutions.
Target 5: 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year;
9 blogs (which included documentaries) Blog https://www.zw.undp.org/content/zimbabwe/en/home/blog/diving-deep-with-a-360-view.html
Main Documentary https://youtu.be/lavaHVicyRw
Mutare Vendors https://youtu.be/a1CU3tiThXo
Harare vendors https://youtu.be/VWfp5k1EGWc
AccLab https://youtu.be/ilUPGRA4XfM
UNVs https://youtu.be/O7AidXKvF8U

Target 1: 5 new sources of data per year Target 2: 6 different type of data sources per year Target 3: 35 new potential solutions per lab per year Target 4: 5 innovation methods per Action Plan Target 5: 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year.

Target: 1.1- 5 new data sources per year -2 new data sources were identified, target not met due to impact of COVID-19; • Use of Knowledge Transfer Africa (KTA) Database on Food Markets • Collective intelligence as a new data sources used at Country office level as a method of data collection to inform urban resilience action plan Target 2 1.2 - 6 different type of data sources per year 4 different type of data sources were identified, target not met due to impact of COVID-19; • Knowledge Transfer Africa (KTA) informal sector market data • Use of radio programming data to inform COVID programming • Viamo mobile survey data • Use of Ureport to survey citizens on impact of COVID-19 Target 3:1.3 - 13 solutions were identified, and target was not reached because of COVID19 Target 4: 1.4 - 3 innovation methods identified target not met due to impact of COVID-19 • Horizon scanning in Makaha to understand the future of small scale gold mining • Virtual reality used to model new ways of living with COVID19 through fashion visualisation • Using the system transformative methodology to tackle different hypotheses under urban resilience action plan Target 6: 2.1 - Accelerator Lab Zimbabwe produced 6 blogs in 2020 accessible - https://www.zw.undp.org/content/zimbabwe/en/home/blog.html , the blog titles are; - Going for Gold - Supporting the extractives industry - Navigating Informality: Patterns of Categorization in Street Vending - Rural-Urban Supply Chain Platform during Covid-19 - Urban Development and Wetland Conservation - Loading: Data-driven analysis of informal market and food supply chains in Zimbabwe - NextGenCities program: Zimbabwe & Food Security 2.2 - Solutions mapping process led to identification of Knowledge Transfer Africa to be used in UN Joint Resilient Food Supply Chain Project with Ministry of Local Government and Ministry of Agriculture. Also work with the police, city council and various bodies that represent vendors and informal sector in Zimbabwe focused on changing the narrative around city vending. 2.3 - Sensemaking Intelligence Report used to define informality as frontier challenge for UNCT 2.4 - At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. Issue mapping process on the informal sector provided some knowledge to Urban Resilience Project on market refurbishment, solutions mapping process on informal sector formulated UNDP’s component of the Resilient Food Supply Chain Project. 3.1- Head of Exploration, Experimentation ad Solution mapping are part of global whatsapp groups and interact with other lab members on a daily/weekly basis. 3.2 - • 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. • Information shared on the first experimentation cycle loop on informality, participation in global calls sharing learnings on informal sector • Information shared of start of second experimentation cycle loop shared on Acclab global calls, global mailing lists and in innovation knowledge sharing unit calls 3.3 - Target met 3.4 - • The Zimbabwe lab began working with Youth Connect and IBUHUB to create a pipeline for capturing and nurturing data science skills. This work builds upon the experiment conducted by the lab to test uncommon sources of informal sector data.

Target 1: 10 new sources of data per year Target 2: 9 different type of data sources per year Target 3: 50 new potential solutions per lab per year Target 4: 10 innovation methods per Action Plan Target 5: 8 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year
